post_text: It's Farmer Jordan Gearlds, BRHS Sr. Down on the farm today with the CEO program!
shared_text:
Central IL CEO
September 10 at 11:46 AM ·

Today the CEO students dressed down & headed to the farm! We spent our morning with Farmer Adam Brown learning about the business side of farming. As a former State Representative, Adam also shared advice on leadership, “Get uncomfortable in order to advance yourself” he said. The students learned about yields, the importance of diversifying your portfolio, honest communication and that it is critical to know your numbers as a business owner.

They also got to walk in the fields, operate a combine & climb the grain bins. It was a great site visit!

Thank you Adam Brown for giving us a glimpse into the world of farming!

Please see the message from John Lawrence, Principal of BRHS. This message was shared with BRHS students on Wed. and Thu. morning.

Students, I have thoroughly enjoyed my years serving as the Principal of Blue Ridge High School. I have many happy memories when I think about my years as your principal. Recently, I have had some struggles with my health which have kept me away from school. I wanted to let you know that I have decided to retire early to focus on getting healthy. I will miss seeing you at school, but know that I will always have your back and support you in any way possible. I am looking forward to spending more time with my family, especially my grandkids. I hope that you have a great year and I wish you all the best!

Mr. Lawrence

post_text:
BRHS Prom Update from Mrs Lagle:

I hope that all of you are staying safe and healthy. I met with school personnel to discuss our options for Prom. Since it is impossible to social distance at a dance and it would involve more than 50 people, we are unable to have a safe Prom. This makes me very sad for the kids. However, we are still planning on having a virtual coronation. Everyone on court will submit a video introducing themselves, who their parents are, and what town they are from. I will put all of the videos together and announce the King and Queen at the end. We will crown the new King and Queen at a scheduled time later to take pictures. We will post these pictures on the district FaceBook page. Mr. Kramer will upload the video to our school YouTube channel on July 25 @ 5:00. Students who are on court will be receiving more details in a separate email.

Please let me know if you have any questions.
Mrs. Lagle
glagle@blueridge18.org

P-EBT is a new special benefit that can help families buy food for their school age children who would normally receive National School Lunch Program (NSLP) free or reduced-priced meals when schools are in session. Families who do not currently receive SNAP benefits but do have children who receive NSLP free or reduced-priced meals will need to apply directly with IDHS.

post_text: ISBE is constantly seeking ways to include student voice in all of the work happening at this agency. ISBE’s Student Advisory Council (SAC) is one of our most important programs for elevating student voice. The SAC is composed of a diverse group of motivated and engaged high school students from across the state who act as student advisers to the State Board. ISBE deeply values diversity of experience on the council. This group of students have the opportunity to see the State Board’s policymakers in action and work with them to provide student perspectives and concerns on the state’s education policies. Selected students participate virtually and attend meetings in Springfield throughout the school year. The 2020-2021 SAC application is now available on ISBE’s website at https://www.isbe.net/studentvoices. The deadline for students to submit applications is May 29, 2020 at 5 p.m. Questions about the program can be sent to jsaba@isbe.net or isbesac@isbe.net.

The City attended a very informative small business assistance teleconference with Congressman Rodney Davis held this morning. The Small Business Administration is offering federal disaster loans to small businesses to get through this difficult economic disaster due to COVID-19.

These loans can be used to pay debts, payroll and other bills. The Interest rates are 3.75% for small businesses and 2.75% for non-profits and can be for up to 30 years and $2 million.

Information is attached to this post, but you may also contact the SBA at 1-800-659-2955 or go to SBA.gov/disaster.
